awd_titl_txt: Inequality and Welfare in a Low Rate Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

The past forty years have been characterized by a secular decline in interest rates and, relatedly, an increase in asset valuations. This proposal consists of two projects that examine the distributional effects of declining interest rates. The first project explores the effect of declining interest rates on wealth inequality. The second examines the welfare implications of declining interest rates by focusing on who gains and who loses from this trend. The project further collects detailed data on high wealth income, and granular data on asset purchases from financial filings and surveys. The project has policy implications in understanding the role of monetary policy on wealth inequality and individual welfare. 

The first project develops a sufficient statistic approach to determine the long-run effect of lower rates on top wealth inequality, as measured by the Pareto exponent of the wealth distribution. Sufficient statistic is estimated by creating a new dataset on the financing of firms owned by billionaires in the US, by combining surveys of fortunes, financial filings, and stock and firm level financial data. The second project will examine the effect of lower rates, or alternatively higher asset valuations, on individual welfare. Using a standard consumption-saving model, the project will derive a sufficient statistic that captures the lifetime effect of lower rates on welfare. The project will then quantify these statistics by using micro-data on net asset purchases across the whole wealth distribution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the last several decades, there has been a secular decline in real interest rates, together with large increases in asset valuations across many asset classes. In “Welfare and Inequality in a Low Rate Environment”, we study the redistributive effects of such trends. Our contribution to the literature is composed of two manuscripts.

In “Wealth Inequality in a Low Rate Environment”, we quantify the effect of lower interest rates on the distribution of wealth across U.S. households, and, in particular, on the concentration of wealth at the very top. The existing literature emphasizes that lower interest rates decrease the growth rate of existing fortunes.  What we point out, however, is that lower interest rates also increase the growth rate of new entrepreneurs, as they make it cheaper to raise capital. To understand which effect dominates in the long-run, we derive a “sufficient statistic” for the effect of interest rates on the Pareto exponent of the wealth distribution (the Pareto exponent of a distribution is a commonly used index measuring the degree of inequality between the rich and the super-rich). The statistic can be estimated using data on the lifetime equity and debt issuance rate of individuals in the right tail of the wealth distribution. We estimate this sufficient statistic using new data on the trajectory of top fortunes in the U.S. Overall, we find that, from 1985 to 2015, the secular decline in interest rates (or more generally of required rates of returns) can account for about 40% of the rise in the U.S. Pareto inequality.

In “Asset-Price Redistribution”, we go beyond the focus on top-wealth inequality and we quantify the redistributive effects of the secular trends in asset prices across the full population. More precisely, we measure the welfare effect of deviations in asset valuations, defined as the amount of income that would make an individual indifferent with the deviation in asset prices. We show that the welfare effect of higher asset prices, at an individual level, can be estimated using the present value of an individual’s net asset sales; intuitively, higher asset valuations benefit prospective sellers and hurt prospective buyers. We estimate this quantity using panel microdata covering the universe of financial transactions in Norway from 1994 to 2019. We show that the welfare effect of a deviation in asset prices is almost uncorrelated with their mechanical revaluation effect (as the former affects sellers and the latter affects owners). We find that rise in asset valuations redistributed from the young towards the old (as older people tend to de-accumulate assets) and from the poor towards the wealthy (as wealthier people tend to issue debt and equity to finance their businesses).

Overall, both of these manuscripts emphasize a key message regarding the redistributive effect of a rise in asset valuations. The existing literature stresses that, in the short-run, a rise in asset valuations has large effects on the distribution of wealth. What we emphasize instead is that that in the longer-run (the focus of our first manuscript) or in terms of welfare (the focus of our second manuscript), what matters is who buys and sells asset prices over time. We develop new methodological tools to estimate these effects and map out the redistributive effect of asset prices. These tools could be applied by researchers to better understand the effect of policy programs that affect asset prices, such as financial and housing regulation or monetary policy.
